text: hey everyone green anthony screen tano
here the internet's
busiest news
and it's a time for a review of this new
shame
album drunk tank pink this is the
sophomore lp
from uk indie rock and post punk outfit
shame
which comes two years after the release
of their breakout record in 2018
songs of praise a record that certainly
checked all of the right post
punk boxes visceral but danceable drums
and bass
angular and textured guitars
very amped shouty lead vocals and
appreciation for atmosphere 2.
plus if you're looking at post punk in
its entirety as a musical movement
this band's approach has a distinctly
english demeanor
so yeah the band certainly had all of
these selling points going for them on
their debut
the issue was that the more i listened
to
this record the less i feel like i knew
who shame was as a band
i mean their approach to this sound and
style isn't exactly unique or anything
and on top of that i found a lot of the
performances
on this project to be sort of mild but
thankfully this new crop of tracks on
drunk tank
pink sounds like the bands are really
playing like their lives depend on it
from the rowdy lead vocals and pointed
rhythm guitars hitting the upbeat on
alphabet to the cerebral and
experimental station wagon at the finish
where the band indulges in these
tense spoken word passages that
eventually build up into this tornado
of noisy drums and guitars for a finale
so
there's definitely an energy a velocity
and electricity to drunk tank pink
that i think its predecessor lacked but
somehow
shame doesn't feel any closer to a
really distinct
sound despite varying up the gamut of
bands they very obviously pull from
but i will say as derivative as some of
these tracks are
the band does have really good taste
cuts like nigel hitter bring
a strong and bold gang of four vibe with
its raw guitars and bass
danceable drums and eccentric lead
vocals meanwhile march days bright
rhythm guitars
tight drums and big gang vocals feel
like what you would get if you grabbed
random members of
franz ferdinand and also parquet courts
and made them go on a blind date it's
simultaneously slick and raw and packed
with these refrains i can't get out of
my head
okay get up oh good some parts of the
track sound
absolutely demented especially in the
second half where the mix is being
swarmed by
all of these uh wailing guitars like
killer bees
the speedy drums and tremolo picked
guitars on born in luton feel like a bit
of a departure on the record as
it's not quite as tight performance wise
as many other cuts here are
it feels like i'm listening to uh i
don't know fugazi if they were slightly
out of practice
even the sad slow despondent guitar
passages that pop in
between the verses feel like a play
right out of their playbook
the nods continue on the track human for
a minute which instrumentally feels like
i'm listening to some
very chairs missing 154 arrow wire
something from the more subdued side of
their early catalog
between the smooth bass and slightly
unnerving guitars and dreamy mix the
band's representation of the sound is
faithful and tasteful but honestly i
can't really say they do anything to put
their own twist on it truly
which is slightly disappointing here and
on other tracks too considering the
obvious amount of
effort that seems to have gone into all
of it especially when you consider the
lyrics here and on other tracks too
are pretty good this i never felt human
before i never felt human before you
approached to the refrains here sort of
teasing out with more words to give more
context more story
is a pretty interesting approach plus
there's a legitimately beautiful guitar
solo in the second leg of this track too
then the track great dog oddly enough
sounds directly like one of this band's
english contemporaries the group idols
one of their more
fast fierce and aggressive cuts even the
super short
blunt lyricism as well as the contrarian
imagery happening within that lyricism
seems like again
something they would do and as a result
i can't really think
of too much to praise about it outside
of the drums and guitars
hitting impeccably hard production-wise
then the track 6-1
features all these sour bright tangy
guitar leads that feel like they are
coming straight out of a
women record like public strain but with
more of a throttling fast postpunk
rhythm section hanging underneath
my favorite moment on the entire track
is probably the seamless
snare transition into the cut harsh
degrees
which features these punishing spiraling
riffs
in 3-4 and while it really is a visceral
and harrowing song and performance
the more maxed out and chaotic it gets
the more it feels like
a song from the self-titled daughter's
record from 2010
now before i close out this review i
should say there was one more moment i
truly found to be impressive in the
tracklist here and that is the song snow
day
we have more panic-inducing guitars on
this one which are set at a
brisk pace some driving drums underneath
these elements set a baseline for some
of the most
tense spoken word passages on the record
which build up occasionally to
these incredible manic freak outs the
track also features a really ambitious
multi-phased
structure too it's easily one of the
more progressive songs on this record on
that front
and as a result the entire track is just
quite a ride
so yeah overall while i can commend the
fact that the band
is really playing with their hearts on
their sleeves on
this one i just love the passion of this
record i can see why so many people have
been
drawn to a project like this so early in
the year
but it's a shame that so many of the
core ideas and elements of
these songs are so common within the
post-punk sphere
and have also been like delivered better
by other groups both like
old school and new school i don't think
it's quite
there honestly but i do come away from
this record with
hope for the future i'm feeling a decent
two strong six
on this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next
